newsitem.title: ZAMBIA: Burundi sanctions meeting postponed - official.
newsitem.headline: Burundi sanctions meeting postponed - official.

text.p: A committee overseeing sanctions on Burundi has postponed a meeting planned for next week to discuss the economic embargo on the troubled Central African country, Zambian officials said on Friday.
"The meeting has been postponed to a later date," a Zambian Foreign Ministry spokesman told Reuters.
The delay was decided at a regional summit in Nairobi earlier this week where African leaders met to discuss the crisis in Burundi's neighbours Zaire and Rwanda.

The committee was due to meet in Lusaka on November 12 to discuss the economic blockade slapped on Burundi after the Tutsi-led army deposed Hutu President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya in a coup on July 25.
"They all agreed that it should be postponed," the spokesman said. No new date had been set.
The regional sanctions committee includes representatives from Tanzania, Kenya, Rwanda, Uganda, Ethiopia and Zambia.
Sanctions have hobbled Burundi in an effort to punish the government of Tutsi military ruler Pierre Buyoya and to force him to talk to ethnic Hutu rebels righting a fierce civil war.
At least 150,000 people, mainly civilians, have been killed in thre years of fighting. In neighbouring Rwanda, up to a million Tutsis and Hutu moderates died in a Hutu-led genocide in 1994.
And in recent weeks fighting has raged in eastern Zaire between government forces and rebels, including ethnic Tutsis, which threatens to engulf the whole region in a new round of violence.
